;;T;;他的故事; 已经震惊了北爱尔兰。 3 月 28 日，杰弗里·唐纳森爵士被警察从床上叫醒，被捕并随后被指控犯有包括强奸在内的性犯罪行为。第二天，耶稣受难日，他辞去了北爱尔兰最大的统一党民主统一党（<小>;DUP;）领导人的职务。法律程序可能需要一年多的时间。政治影响是立竿见影且巨大的。

;

;;DUP; 现在在三年内有了第四位领导人 —使得威斯敏斯特的保守党看起来几乎稳定。临时负责人加文·罗宾逊（如图，杰弗里爵士右侧）很可能会永久获得这份工作。这位温和、善于表达的东贝尔法斯特议员;议员;出身于律师出身，是;DUP;有史以来最年轻的领导人。如果他能够将<小>;民主统一党;团结起来，他就有能力帮助该党吸引更年轻、更自由的选民，以扭转工会主义最近的衰落。但他的工作还有待完成。

;
;
;
;
;;
;

;杰弗里爵士的被捕对他的心理造成了残酷的打击。自从煽动性的新教牧师伊恩·佩斯利 (Ian Paisley) 于 1971 年创立<小>;民主统一党;以来，该党就将信仰与激烈的部落保卫与英国联盟融为一体。它反对堕胎、同性婚姻和周日延长商店营业时间。并非所有成员都有宗教信仰，但他们都知道; 他们正在加入一个宗教团体;。

;

;61 岁的杰弗里爵士是祈祷与政治结合的化身。从二十岁出头起，他就被认为是未来的工会领袖，在公开场合他很虔诚，翻领上戴着古老的基督教鱼标志。他被捕后，该党立即将他停职，并着手从其网站主页上删除他的形象。值得注意的是，据了解杰弗里爵士否认了这些指控，并将极力反驳这些指控。

;

;这一事件也动摇了北爱尔兰的立场政府权力下放，是在中断两年后恢复政府后不到两个月的时间。一月份，杰弗里爵士带领他的政党重新达成权力共享安排; 与最大的民族主义政党新芬党 (Sinn Féin) 合作，新芬党希望建立一个统一的爱尔兰，并在 2022 年的选举中击败了<小>;民主统一党; (DUP)，取得第二名。 迄今为止，他一直坚称英国和英国之间的贸易壁垒北爱尔兰是英国脱欧的后果，必须被清除，但在达成软化边界的协议后，他改变了主意。他<小>;掉头;的速度让很多人感到惊讶。他的几位高级同事反对此举。

;

;在任期间，;DUP; 与新芬党之间的关系一直很紧张。就像;延长蜜月;，以微笑、大度和温暖的跨社区姿态为特征。短期内不存在权力下放失败的可能性。 <小>;民主统一党;最终承诺加入政府，但并不打算退出。尽管杰弗里爵士（威斯敏斯特的<小>;议员;）是党的领袖，但他并不是权力下放政府的成员。但随着合作伙伴的主要工会赞助商消失，这种温暖可能会消失。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;该党的许多支持者对该党与新芬党合作的渴望仍然感到不安。如果笑容和拍照机会减少，部长们将被迫面对北爱尔兰的深层问题。经过两年的公共服务退化，各部门都要求增加资金；然而，拥有部分增税权力的权力下放政府既不愿意大幅增税，也不愿意进行抵消性预算削减。

;

;对于现在，北爱尔兰各种政治背景的人们都对杰弗里爵士的指控感到震惊。年轻时，他是英国保守党政治家伊诺克·鲍威尔 (Enoch Powell) 的门徒，后者于 1974 年离开托利党，成为南唐郡的阿尔斯特统一党 (;UUP;) ;MP;。 （杰弗里爵士后来退出了<小>;联合统一党;，加入了一个被鲍威尔嘲笑为“新芬党”的政党。）鲍威尔曾经说过：“所有的政治生活，除非在一个幸福的时刻被中流切断，否则就会结束。”失败中。”杰弗里爵士的政治生涯现在如何结束取决于法院。;■;

;;“M;<小>;r总统！” ;哈维尔·米雷 (Javier Milei) 在二月份的保守党政治行动会议 (;CPAC;) 上见到唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 时几乎无法控制自己。两人拥抱并交换口号，特朗普多次吟诵“让阿根廷再次伟大”，而阿根廷新总统则大喊“;Viva la libertad, carajo;”（“该死的自由万岁”）作为回应。

;

;萨尔瓦多受欢迎的独裁总统纳伊布·布克莱(Nayib Bukele) 已经在会议上发表了讲话。 “他们说全球主义将在 CPAC 上消亡，”他对欣喜若狂的共和党人说。 “我来这里是想告诉你，在萨尔瓦多，它已经死了。”巴西极右翼前总统雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗 (Jair Bolsonaro) 是 2023 年的明星嘉宾。他和特朗普一样，在没有证据的情况下声称自己连任的努力因欺诈而受挫。他的支持者还试图发动叛乱。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这些场景表明特朗普与拉丁美洲极右翼领导人之间建立了无缝的国际联盟。其成员还包括智利的何塞·安东尼奥·卡斯特 (José Antonio Kast)，他在之前的一次 ;CPAC; 活动中发表了讲话。这一新右翼受益于特朗普的影响力。它已经放弃了更加共识的保守政治形式，转而支持激进的文化战争。

;

;它的崛起始于令人惊讶的事情博索纳罗先生于 2018 年在巴西获胜，布克莱先生于 2019 年获胜。在智利，新的极右翼共和党创始人卡斯特先生在 2021 年总统决选中获得了 44% 的选票，他的政党赢得了 2023 年宪法委员会的选举。米莱先生在 11 月赢得了自己的意外胜利。秘鲁和哥伦比亚政坛中激进右翼的未来领导人展开了角逐。

;

;与欧洲和北美的老对手不同，拉丁美国的极右翼势力并没有植根于公众对不受控制的移民的焦虑的沃土。 （尽管最近由于数百万逃离本国腐朽独裁统治的委内瑞拉人的到来，这已成为一个问题。）

;

;新组织共有三个标志。首先是强烈反对堕胎、同性恋和妇女权利。正如两位学者林赛·梅卡 (Lindsay Mayka) 和艾米·埃里卡·史密斯 (Amy Erica Smith) 所说，“将他们团结在一起的是对传统社会等级制度的肯定”。第二个是对犯罪和维护公民安全的强硬路线。第三个是坚决反对社会民主主义，更不用说共产主义了，这导致一些人想要一个更小的国家。

;

;有一些共同因素他们的攀登也是如此。他们受到了危机感的帮助——巴西和阿根廷的腐败和经济停滞、萨尔瓦多的帮派暴力以及智利时而暴力的“社会爆炸”。

;;

;怀抱表兄弟

;

;但每位领导人都采用了这些意识形态元素的不同组合。智利天主教大学的克里斯托瓦尔·罗维拉表示，拉丁美洲的极右翼是“表兄弟，而不是兄弟”。 “它们很相似，但并不完全相同。”

;

;博尔索纳罗先生的选民都是福音派人士，他向他们呼吁捍卫传统家庭，以军队、警察和农民为形式的独裁右翼则担心土地入侵和农村犯罪。但他对自由市场和财政严格性态度冷淡。布克莱先生将安全作为他第一个总统任期的基石，通过拘留萨尔瓦多 640 万公民中的 74,000 多人来打击犯罪团伙。他的经济政策不太明确，尽管他在;CPAC;上声称，但他并不是不言而喻的“反全球化主义者”。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;米雷先生当选是因为他承诺让阿根廷摆脱长期滞胀并消除他所谓的腐败政治“种姓”。他自称为“无政府资本主义者”，是奥地利自由市场经济学派的粉丝。与特朗普不同，他既不是经济民族主义者，也不是贸易保护主义者。他最近才在道德问题上采纳了同侪的立场。他的政府支持一项推翻阿根廷堕胎法的法案，并表示这将消除公共行政部门中具有性别意识的语言。 Bukele 先生也效仿了。

;

;Kast 先生试图将保守道德纳入其政党支持的宪法草案中，这也是该草案被拒绝的原因之一在公民投票中。他希望在安全和反对移民方面采取严厉的政策。 “我们应该关闭边界并修建战壕，”他说。他希望“缩小国家规模并降低税收负担”。博尔索纳罗先生是气候变化怀疑论者和反疫苗者，但卡斯特先生不是。

;

;民主是为了你，不是为了我

;

;右翼民粹主义者对民主也有不同的态度。博尔索纳罗试图颠覆选举结果（目前正在接受警方调查），这表明他不是民主党人。布克莱先生蔑视制衡。他在降低谋杀率方面的成功使他非常受欢迎，使他能够超越宪法任期限制并在二月份赢得第二个任期。

;

;阿根廷历史学家卡洛斯·马拉穆德 (Carlos Malamud) 表示，米莱先生“对民主制度的蔑视是显而易见的”，并指出他决定打破惯例，向一群支持者而不是国会发表就职演说。但是，他补充道，米莱先生可能还知道他需要将议会纳入政府。

;

;“我是一名民主党人，”卡斯特先生坚持认为，他的对手也同意。 “在安全和缩小国家规模方面，我们与博尔索纳罗有着相同的观点，”他说。 “但这并不意味着我们与米雷、博尔索纳罗或布克莱一样。”正如卡斯特先生指出的那样，每个国家的情况都有很大不同，这决定了政策选择。

;

;各个领导人的前景也是如此。布克莱先生是迄今为止最成功的人，整个地区都有可能效仿的人，而且他无限期掌权没有明显的障碍。相比之下，博索纳罗活跃的政治生涯很可能已经结束。选举法院禁止他在 2030 年（届时他将年满 75 岁）作为候选人，因为他在与外国大使的会面中诋毁投票制度。他可能会因明显试图组织军事政变反对选举失败而被监禁；他否认这一点，并声称自己是政治迫害的受害者。

;

;Milei 先生的未来是可以争取的。如果他成功抑制通货膨胀，他可能会在 2025 年的中期选举中变得更加强大。但如果他拒绝与国会和省长妥协，他可能会在此之前遇到麻烦。在智利，卡斯特先生似乎在宪法草案上发挥了过大的作用。 2025 年的选举可能会导致中右翼掌权。该观点的一位有影响力的人物认为卡斯特先生无法代表现代智利的多样性。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;最终，该团体受到围绕共同政治话语构建的国际网络的约束和文化参考。卡斯特是价值观政治网络的主席，该组织此前由匈牙利民粹主义领导人欧尔班维克托的盟友领导。西班牙极右翼政党 Vox 组织了马德里论坛，这是一个由志同道合的政治家组成的网络，主要来自所谓的拉丁美洲“伊比利亚圈”。

;

;这些聚会提供了分享经验的机会，有时甚至更多。布克莱先生的顾问来自委内瑞拉流亡反对派。特朗普的积极分子已经出现在拉丁美洲的选举中。最近，博尔索纳罗因害怕被捕而在匈牙利驻巴西利亚大使馆避难了两个晚上。

;

;但没有任何中央方向的迹象或协调。拉美右翼长期以来一直声称圣保罗论坛是拉美左翼分子的聚会，是一个高度组织的阴谋。所有的证据都表明，这是一个松散的友谊网络。右翼同行似乎也是如此。;■;

;;F;;钓鱼靴;。滨冢博之和千秋最希望在车库的废墟下找到儿子心爱的钓鱼靴。滨祖家位于日本能登半岛北端的珠洲，是在;1 月 1 日发生大地震;。截至3月底，这场灾难已造成244人死亡。滨祖一家和他们的孩子幸存下来，但像大多数邻居一样，地震发生近 100 天后，这个家庭才刚刚开始重建生活。一名救灾志愿者正在用挖掘机帮助清理滨冢一家的废墟，半岛需要数年时间才能恢复。

;

;元旦下午 4 点左右开始震动。 “大海看起来很黑，而且在旋转，”滨冢先生回忆道。这次震级为 7.6 级的地震是自 2011 年东日本大地震以来袭击该国的最强地震，该地震引发了大规模海啸并引发了福岛核泄漏。诺托的地震活动引发了一个被称为“液化”的过程，通常固体的地面变成液体状的物质，导致道路扭曲和结构扭曲。在半岛的主要城市轮岛，一个市场发生火灾，留下一片荒地。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;整个诺托，残骸遍布各处。尽管较新的建筑幸存下来，但许多传统的木屋被夷为平地。仍有近万人流离失所。居民们努力维护自己的尊严。在轮岛的一个疏散中心，一群妇女正在搅拌绿茶，并将糖果放在漆盘上，这是该镇的标志性工艺品。然而悲伤和震惊从来都隐藏在表面之下。一位轮岛人在为记者送达后崩溃了，回忆起她失去的朋友。

;

;如果不是的话，能登的损失可能会更严重不适合日本;对灾害风险的关注< /a>; 祝你好运。这次地震发生在一个半岛上，该半岛人口只占该国人口的一小部分，占其;GDP;的比例也很小。政府估计，损失将达到约 2.6 万日元（170 亿美元）左右，即使与 2016 年南部中型城市熊本发生的另一场大地震（造成 5 万日元的损失）相比，这个数额也是可以控制的。 （;东京或日本中部地区出现令人担忧的地震;会造成更多。）尽管政府发布了重大海啸警报，但幸运的是，海浪比预期的要小。居民基本上都听从了撤离的呼吁。

;

;然而，日本的每一次地震都是未来灾难的教训。能登半岛位于日本主岛北部边缘，地处偏远，使得救援和恢复工作变得复杂。通往地区首府金泽的道路被毁，地震发生后的几周内，原本需要两个小时的车程现在变成了九个小时。 “我们无法前往计划好的地方，因为道路被封锁了，”轮岛市政府的一名官员说。港口也遭到破坏，难以通过船只运送物资。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;能登半岛也处于日本人口转型的前沿。该地区是该国最古老的地区之一，近一半的人口年龄超过 65 岁，而全国这一比例约为 30%。老年居民在灾害期间尤其容易受到伤害。东日本大地震后因疾病或压力而死亡的 3,200 人中，近 90% 的人年龄超过 65 岁。

;

;日本不仅人口老龄化，其基础设施也在老龄化。日本战后繁荣时期铺设的水管即将达到使用寿命，但公用事业公司缺乏资金来投资升级。人口减少正在侵蚀他们的利润。在诺托，地震后有多达 135,000 户家庭断水。抽水马桶仍然很难获得。志愿者团体帮助建立了临时设施。

;

;新技术或许能够帮助解决其中一些挑战。在半岛各地的疏散中心，居民可以使用特殊的水槽和浴缸装置来洗手或淋浴，这些装置可以自我回收水，这是由日本初创公司 Wota 提供的，Wota 是一家生产分散式水处理基础设施的公司。部署无人机帮助向难以到达的沿海社区运送物资。这样一来，从大本营出发的送货只需 16 分钟，而步行则需要 5 至 6 小时。数字<小>;身份证;卡使追踪有需要的人变得更加容易——官员们希望这场灾难能够鼓励它们的广泛使用。 “我们希望使该地区更具弹性，而不仅仅是铺设更多具体的混凝土，”石川县（包括能登半岛）副知事西垣敦子说。

; ; l ; ; ; ast ast ; ; ; ;中国领导人Xi Jinping访问了;是该国最低的。 ;房价;在其最大的城市中跌倒。该省的; GDP ;在2023年仅增长了2.6％。更糟糕的是，其名义; gdp ;在调整通货膨胀之前几乎没有增长，这表明它在深<< a href =“ https://www.economist.com/finance-and-yconomics/2023/08/10/deflation-anddeflation-and-default-haunt-chinas-economy- p data-component =“段落” class =“ CSS-121TNHW E1TT35BK0”>;永远不要担心：Xi先生有一个计划。在访问期间，他敦促省里的听众培育“新生产力”。此后，这句话在官方报纸和官方集会上多次出现。它在;上个月上个月的《上个月的》 “两次会议” ;，《中国橡皮图集议会及其顾问机构的年度会议》。北京大学的王先清在一本关于这一主题的新书的序言中将这个词比作“改革开放”，这个公式概括了中国在 1978 年之后拥抱市场力量的情况。他写道，这些词即使在今天仍然“闪耀”，暗示“新生产力”将具有类似的持久力。 /div>;

; ;

;这些闪亮的单词是什么意思？中国官员正在寻找为国家经济提供动力的方法。多年来，其生产力依赖于劳动力的动员和资本的积累。该国的劳动力从1996年到2015年增长了1亿人口。根据智囊团的亚洲生产力组织的数据，该国的资本库存从2001年的; GDP ;的258％增加到了二十年后的349％。在2007 - 09年全球金融危机之后，大部分资本积累采用了新财产和基础设施的形式。

;

;现在中国的劳动力对财产的收缩和需求具有; /a>;：搬到中国城市的人数较少，不再确保房地产的投机性收益，并且潜在的购房者不愿意提前购买公寓，以防万一不良的开发商在建造完成之前用完现金。房地产低迷损害了消费者信心，并剥夺了地方政府从土地销售中获得的重要收入。 Even after China abandoned its strict covid-19 controls, the economic recovery has been ;muted and uneven;.支出还不足以充分利用中国现有的生产力。 As a consequence, according to one measure, deflation has persisted for three quarters in a row.

;;
;;
;

;At China's stage of development, economies typically pivot towards services.但政府的心却在别处。这场大流行增加了对中国制成品的需求，从外科口罩到健身自行车。美国对“瓶颈技术”的出口管制也产生了对本土替代品的需求，从光刻机到航空级不锈钢。 China's 14th five-year plan, which spans 2021-25, promised to maintain manufacturing's share of ;GDP;, which had declined from almost a third in 2006 to just over a quarter in 2020 (see chart).

;

;In its quest for a sophisticated, yet self-contained, manufacturing system, China has long employed a variety of helpful policies. Its Ministry of Education, for example, recently approved a new undergraduate concentration in ;high-end semiconductor science; and engineering. China's spending on more explicit industrial policies, including subsidies, tax breaks and cheap credit, amounted to 1.7% of ;GDP ;in 2019, according to the Centre for Strategic and International Studies, a think-tank—more than three times the percentage spent by America.

;
;
;
;
;;
;

;“What China really wants to be is the leader of the next industrial revolution,” says Tilly Zhang of Gavekal Dragonomics, a consultancy 。这将要求它升级传统产业，打破外国对现有技术的束缚，并为未来产业开辟新道路。尽管中央政府的野心令人印象深刻，甚至令人不安，但如果没有资金短缺的地方政府和信心不足的私营企业家的帮助，它就不可能成功。 As such, the new slogan may betray a damaging hyperopia—long-sightedness that is blinding the leadership to more immediate economic concerns.

;;

;The owl spreads its wings

;

;To Barry Naughton of the University of California, San Diego, who confesses to reading some Hegel in his younger days, the phrase “new productive forces” evokes the “dialectical” idea that an accumulation of quantitative changes can result in a qualitative break or sudden leap, as Hegel put it, like when an incremental increase in temperature turns water into steam.与此同时，马克思指出，当新的生产力在经济中取得足够的分量时，它们就可以重塑社会秩序：“手磨坊给你带来了封建领主的社会，”他写道，“蒸汽磨坊给了你一个工业资本主义的社会。 ”。 New productive forces, then, can be a big deal.

;

;But in presenting the concept, Mr Xi has said that the test for new productive forces will be improvements in “total factor productivity”, a term lifted not from Marx, but from mainstream economics.它是指不能归因于可衡量投入（例如资本、劳动力和人力资本）增加的产出增加。 In mixing Marxist and neoclassical concepts, new productive forces is a “strange hybrid beast”, says Mr Naughton.

;

;According to Mr Xi, the new productive forces will flow from the application of science and technology to production.这句话是一个信号，表明中国的技术推动应该比现在更加雄心勃勃，并更紧密地融入经济生产。中国领导人承诺“举全国之力”推动技术自力更生。 3月份公布的中央政府预算将科技支出增加了10%，达到3710亿元人民币（500亿美元），是所有部门中增幅最大的。 Frugal innovation, this is not.

;

;Nor is it China's first assay at the problem. In 2006 a 15-year plan set national targets to increase research-and-development (;R;&;D;) spending, cut dependence on foreign technology and lift technology's contribution to growth 。它还确定了16个“大型项目”，例如建造中国自己的大型客机和在月球上着陆探测器。这些主要是复制现有技术的尝试。 In 2010, after the global financial crisis, China changed tack, lavishing some of its heavy stimulus on a variety of “strategic emerging industries”, including new kinds of information technology, renewable energy and ;electric vehicles; (;EV;s)—many of which were still embryonic.

;

;Six years later, China shifted emphasis again.其“创新驱动发展战略”表达了对世界正处于另一场工业革命之中的信念。 Advances in digital technologies, the internet of things, green technologies and ;artificial intelligence; (;AI;) promised breakthroughs across swathes of the economy.中国的新战略并没有选择各种新兴产业，而是强调了相互增强的技术集群。中国的目标是到本世纪中叶成为创新的“世界强国”。 By 2020 it was spending almost 2.9trn yuan (2.8% of ;GDP;) on science and technology, according to Rhodium Group, a consultancy.如果算上慷慨的税收减免的话，政府的贡献超过了60%。在获奖者中，六分之一最终进入了大学或研究机构。 Roughly 60% flowed to companies.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Naughton has called China's innovation strategy “the greatest single commitment of government resources to an industrial policy objective in history”.国家必须为此展示什么？迄今为止，结果好于任何中等收入国家的预期。 But they are not quite as impressive as China's leaders might have hoped.

;

;In ;e-commerce;, fintech, high-speed trains and renewable energy, China is at or near the technological边境。 The same is strikingly apparent in ;EV;s, success with which helped China last year become the world's biggest exporter of cars.在智库澳大利亚政策研究所确定的 64 项“关键”技术清单中，根据该领域最有影响力的论文数量，中国在除 11 项之外的所有技术上均领先世界。 The country is number one in 5;G; and 6;G; communications, as well as biomanufacturing, nanomanufacturing and additive manufacturing. It is also out in front in drones, radar, robotics and sonar, as well as post-quantum cryptography.

;

;White heat

;

;China has also made good progress in broader measures of a country's innovation “ecosystem”.全球创新指数由世界知识产权组织发布，综合了约 80 个指标，涵盖基础设施、法规和市场条件，以及研究工作、专利奖项和引用次数。 A middle-income country with China's ;GDP ;per person would expect to rank in the 60s. China ranks 12th.

;

;The economic impact of these achievements is harder to measure.中国的“战略性新兴产业”清单自2010年推出以来一直在不断变化，因此很难追踪进展情况。中国国家统计局的两名官员曾感叹，纳入标准，特别是产品层面的标准“模糊”。如何知道锅炉算“节能”还是复合材料算“高性能”？ Nonetheless, China's statisticians estimate that strategic emerging industries accounted for 13.4% of ;GDP ;in 2021, up from 7.6% in 2014 but below the original target for 2020 of 15%. By comparison, the value added by property building and services (ignoring upstream links to steel, iron-ore and other such industries) was about 12%.

;

;Although these gains are impressive, China's leaders are not content.他们对美国的技术禁运和最近的技术胜利感到震惊。对芯片和芯片制造设备销售的全面出口管制暴露了​​中国对外国零部件、软件和设备的依赖。 America's advances in ;AI; have also prompted reflection. ;AI; was an industry in which China thought it had an edge. The country's leaders were shocked by the introduction in 2022 of Chat;GPT;, a large language model developed by Open;AI;.

;

;China's progress has also been hurt by its own leaders. 2021 年，他们严厉打击了中国许多领先的科技公司，指责它们处理数据不当、阻碍竞争和剥削零工工人。这场监管风暴针对的是阿里巴巴和美团等面向消费者的“平台”公司，而不是先进制造商或其他“硬科技”公司。然而，对投资者信心的损害却难以遏制。 The disfavoured platform companies, with their huge troves of data, are also leading investors in many frontier technologies, such as ;AI;, that China's leaders are keen to foster. The country's big internet firms cut their ;R;&;D; spending by almost 7% in the first half of 2023, compared with a year earlier, according to Rhodium.

;

;Total-factor productivity growth—Mr Xi's preferred test of new productive force—has also slowed.中国2006年推出的科技计划意味着其对经济增长的贡献率将上升至60%。 Instead, it has fallen to less than a third, according to calculations by Louis Kuijs of ;S;&;P; Global Ratings, a credit-rating agency.因此，中国正遭受着自己版本的“索洛悖论”：除了生产率统计数据之外，你到处都可以看到一个新的技术时代。 These setbacks and shortcomings may explain the perceived need for a fresh slogan to shake things up.

;

;The country's innovation push now seems split into three 。它决心复制世界其他国家可能会试图否认的“窒息”技术。第二个目标是发明世界其他地区尚未创造的技术。今年1月，科技部会同其他六部委发布了一份“未来产业”清单，其中许多产业比过去的战略性新兴产业更具开创性。它们包括光子计算、脑机接口、核聚变和数字双胞胎——医生可以监测患者的数字拟像，以监测现实生活中可能出现的疾病。 China's government is encouraging laboratories and research institutes to spend more than half of their basic research money on scientists under 35 years of age, in the belief they are more likely to make the breakthroughs the country needs.

;

;These moonshots could be seen as a folly China can ill afford—a distraction from the dogged pursuit of self-reliance, which requires homegrown versions of technologies that China can no longer count on importing from abroad.但Gavekal的张女士表示，中国领导人希望未来产业能够在未来的科技战中为国家提供“讨价还价的筹码”，从而间接为国家的技术主权做出贡献。 If America threatens to cut off China's access to a vital input, China can retaliate in kind.

;

;Round the bend

;

;Chinese commentators often talk about “overtaking at the curve”. China's success in ;EV;s, following its longstanding failure to displace incumbent makers of traditional vehicles, demonstrates that it can sometimes be easier to make advances in fields that are not already occupied by well-entrenched incumbents.北京对外经济贸易大学的毛杰及其合著者表示，2000年至2012年中国的科技政策对发酵行业生产率的提升最为显着，而不是国内已经成熟的行业或国外。在打游击战争时，毛泽东主张先占领农村再进城。 In the same way, China may be marching into wilder and woollier areas of technological discovery, where its long entrenched adversaries have a smaller advantage.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;A third objective is to upgrade existing industries.北京大学的王勇认为，“即使是最传统的农业，只要采用革命性的技术，也能形成新的生产力”。他引用了使用大数据的自动化种植或选择性育种。 At the two sessions, the annual meetings of China's parliament and its advisory body, a delegate from a prominent state-owned distillery even argued that the new productive forces can be found in hard spirits.

;

;The pursuit of these goals will be expensive.过去十到十五年的一个教训是，大量的货币并不能保证黑格尔式的生产转型。 But a lack of spending will surely preclude one.

;

;It must therefore worry China's leaders that local governments' budgets are stretched and animal spirits are low 。 In the past, much of the money for China's tech push has come from local-government funds that raise money from land sales and “special bonds”. Their revenues fell by more than a fifth from 2020 to 2023.

;;O;;ne particularly ; undignified aspect of the cryptocurrency crash has been the habit of referring to ;Sam Bankman-Fried;, who on March 28th was sentenced to 25 years in prison for fraud in the collapse of his crypto exchange, as ;SBF;. Such triple-initialising has become ubiquitous in America. Hillary Rodham Clinton likes to be known as ;HRC;, while Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a progressive member of Congress, is widely called ;AOC; (confusing the French, who take this to refer to wine and cheese of ;appellation d'origine contrôlée;). On the far right Marjorie Taylor Greene, a conspiracy-theorist member of Congress from Georgia, styles herself on social media as ;MTG;. The late ;Ruth Bader Ginsburg;, a Supreme Court justice, became, to her bemused surprise, the subject of an Oscar-nominated documentary entitled “;RBG;”. Now the court has ;KBJ; (;Ketanji Brown Jackson;).

;

;The habit is global. Germans refer to Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, a former defence minister, as ;AKK;, and to Sabine Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger, a former justice minister, as ;SLS ;(both are apparently too much of a mouthful even for native-speakers). French ex-politician Dominique Strauss-Kahn is called ;DSK;. Russians know Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin as ;VVP;, who got his start in the ;KGB;. ;The United Arab Emirates; (;UAE;) has as its de facto ruler Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, or ;MBZ;, and in Saudi Arabia the man in charge is Crown Prince Muhammad bin Salman, commonly shortened to ;MBS;. In Mexico, meanwhile, the president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, is known as ;AMLO;—an alarming escalation to four digits.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;All this is getting out of hand, not least in politics. Initials can create more confusion than convenience. It is one thing to streamline discussions with abbreviations that everyone knows, such as ;CIA; or ;FBI;, but many sensible people will have no idea who ;MTG;是。 Abbreviations have already infected the modern workplace (the ;CFO; and ;COO; are typically ;OOO; ;WFH; to consider ;ROI;), not to mention social media (;TBH; ;IDK; ;WTF; a ;PSA; is). Politics is messy enough without gratuitous clutter.

;

;At issue is substance as well as style. Triple-initialisation is all too often an attempt to claim iconic status. American politicians are tempted to capitalise on the greatest of their lot, Franklin Delano Roosevelt: ;FDR;. He had had the nickname from birth but as president it proved helpful to journalists writing headlines. ;FDR;'s three-initial glamour was self-consciously mimicked by his fellow Democratic successors in the White House, John F. Kennedy (;JFK;) and Lyndon B. Johnson (< small>;LBJ;), as well as by ;JFK;'s younger brother, Robert F. Kennedy (whose son, Robert, is now a ;maverick presidential candidate; seeking to brand himself as ;RFK; junior ）。 When Johnson was still an ambitious member of Congress he told his staffers, “;FDR;-;LBJ;, ;FDR;-;LBJ; 。 Do you get it? What I want is for them to start thinking of me in terms of initials.” Not leaving it to chance, he named his daughters Lynda Bird Johnson and Luci Baines Johnson and his dog Little Beagle Johnson. Richard Nixon, too, wanted the Kennedyesque cachet of initials, but botched the job: he entitled his memoirs “;RN;”, to no avail.

;

;Is it too much to ask that politicians go by their proper names? Exceptions should be rare and inspirational. Martin Luther King junior, the champion of the civil-rights movement, is properly honoured as ;MLK;. If a leader should manage to do the equivalent of leading a great power through the Great Depression and the second world war—or to resolve the Cuban missile crisis, or to uphold the rights of oppressed minorities—then he or she will have earned those exalted three initials. But the digital currency is all too easily devalued. ;■;

;;T;;he Gila; monster is a poisonous North American lizard that measures around 50 centimetres and sports a distinctive coat of black and orange scales. This lethargic reptile, which mostly dwells underground and eats just three to four times a year, is the unlikely inspiration for one of pharma's biggest blockbusters: a ;new generation of weight-loss drugs; that has patients—and ;investors;—in a frenzy. Originally made for diabetes, evidence is growing that they also have benefits in diseases of the heart, kidney, liver and beyond.

;

;Since the late 1980s scientists believed that a gut hormone called glucagon-like peptide-1 (;GLP;-1), which is secreted by the intestines after a meal, could help treat diabetes. ;GLP;-1 increases the production of insulin (a hormone that lowers blood-sugar levels) and reduces the production of glucagon (which increases blood-sugar levels). But ;GLP;-1 is broken down by enzymes in the body very quickly, so it sticks around for only a few minutes. If it were to be used as a drug, therefore, patients would have faced the unwelcome prospect of needing ;GLP;-1 injections every hour.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In 1990 John Eng, a researcher at the Veterans Affairs Medical Centre in The Bronx, discovered that exendin-4, a hormone found in the venom of the Gila monster, was similar to human ;GLP;-1. Crucially, the exendin-4 released after one of the monster's rare meals is more resistant to enzymatic breakdown than ;GLP;-1, staying in its body for hours.十多年后，由美国制药巨头礼来公司和生物技术公司 Amylin Pharmaceuticals 开发的蜥蜴激素的合成版本艾塞那肽在美国被批准用于治疗糖尿病。 This breakthrough spurred other firms to develop more effective and longer-lasting ;GLP;-1 medications as a treatment option for diabetes, beyond injections of insulin.

;

;Scientists had also been aware that ;GLP;-1 had another side-effect: it slowed the rate of “gastric emptying”, which allows food to stay in the stomach for longer and suppresses appetite.但最初并没有认真追求潜在的减肥益处。 It was only in 2021 that Novo Nordisk, a Danish firm, showed data from a clinical trial where overweight or obese patients were put on a weekly dose of its ;GLP;-1-based diabetic drug, semaglutide, which was then being marketed under the name Ozempic, for 68 weeks. The results were dramatic—participants had lost 15% of their body weight, on average.

;;

;Fat profits

;

;The medicines that mimic the ;GLP;-1 hormone then became blockbusters. With close to half of the ;world's population; expected to be obese or overweight by 2030, according to the World Obesity Federation, demand for these drugs is surging—Bloomberg, a data provider, estimates that these medications will hit $80bn in yearly sales by then. The market is projected to grow by 26% per year in the next 5 years, compared with 16% per year for oncology drugs and 4% per year for immunology medicines, the two other biggest areas.

;;
;;
;

;So far only three ;GLP;-1 drugs have been approved to treat obese or overweight individuals: liraglutide and semaglutide, developed by Novo;和替泽帕肽，由礼来公司生产。但该市场已经吸引了一波竞争对手（见图1）。 Bloomberg tracks close to ;100 wannabe drugs; in the development pipeline. Most new therapies hope to outdo semaglutide and tirzepatide by crafting drugs that are easier to take, cause fewer side-effects or deliver more effective weight loss (see chart 2).

;

;Start with convenience.索马鲁肽和替泽帕肽都是需要每周注射一次的注射剂。停止用药，一年内体重大部分恢复。美国大型生物技术公司安进正在开发一种抗肥胖药物，每月服用一次，并希望即使在治疗结束后减肥效果也能持续。 ;AMG;133 activates receptors for ;GLP;-1 while blocking receptors of glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (;GIP;), a hormone secreted in the small intestine in response to food intake that stimulates the production of both insulin and glucagon. The company is now conducting clinical trials to find out if patients can, over time, be gradually weaned towards smaller doses.

;;

;Switching from injections to pills would also make the drugs a lot more tolerable for those who dislike needles. Novo 正在开发口服索马鲁肽，其效果与注射剂一样好。但丸剂需要的活性成分量是注射剂的20倍，并且必须每天服用。 With semaglutide in short supply, Novo has had to push back the oral version's launch. ;

;Another drawback of ;GLP;-1-based medicines is the nausea and vomiting that frequently accompanies their use.丹麦生物技术公司 Zealand Pharma 正在开发一种基于另一种称为胰淀素的激素的药物，这种激素与胰岛素一起在胰腺中产生，以响应食物的摄入。 But unlike ;GLP;-1, which suppresses appetite, amylin induces satiety, or the feeling of fullness after a meal.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Adam Steesburg, boss of Zealand, says that in most people a hormone called leptin is released from fat tissue that signals to the brain that the body is full.肥胖者对这种激素不敏感。临床研究表明，胰淀素类似物可以使人们对瘦素再次敏感，帮助他们更早停止进食。饱腹感不仅不会降低食欲，还可能减少恶心的感觉。 Mr Steesburg says that results from early-stage trials suggest that its drug could achieve similar weight loss as ;GLP;-1 drugs, but with less nausea and vomiting.

;

;The slimming drugs aren't just for shedding pounds. Because obesity is linked to over 200 health issues, including strokes, kidney problems and fatty liver, ;GLP;-1 drugs are proving useful for more than just obesity.

;

;A recent clinical trial by Novo that ran for five years and enrolled more than 17,500 participants found that semaglutide cut the risk of serious heart issues like heart attacks, strokes, or death from heart disease by 20%。 Novo believes that the heart benefits of the treatment are not due to weight loss alone, because the reduction in the risk of cardiovascular problems occurred early, before patients lost weight. ;

;Another weight-loss drug, survodutide, being developed by Boehringer Ingelheim, a German drug company, and Zealand, has shown promising results in being able to treat a serious liver condition called metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (;MASH;).这是由肝脏中过多脂肪堆积引起的，可能导致肝癌或肝功能衰竭。在最近一项对 295 名患者进行的试验中，83% 的患者在接受 survodutide 治疗后病情得到显着改善，而服用安慰剂的患者只有 18% 的病情得到显着改善。 Survodutide targets receptors for ;GLP;-1 and glucagon. ;

;Gut meets brain

;

;While a lot of focus has been on the action of these medicines on improving metabolic health, scientists are now uncovering that these drugs also engage with the brain and immune system, by interacting with ;GLP;-1 receptors in the brain.

;

;Daniel Drucker, a diabetes researcher at Mount Sinai Hospital in Toronto, found that in mice suffering from extensive inflammation throughout the body, ;GLP;-1 drugs reduced the condition, but only when the receptors in the brain weren't blocked.当小鼠的大脑受体被阻断或基因删除时，药物的抗炎特性就会丧失。 This suggests that the ;GLP;-1 drugs tame inflammation by acting on the brain cells.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For some this suggests that these drugs might be useful for treating brain disorders that are characterised by inflammation, such as Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease, both of which are characterised by inflammation in the brain. ;;I;;N 1960 America ;had around 18,000 nuclear weapons. It also had detailed plans for how to use them. Had it implemented them, 275m people in the Soviet Union would have been killed in the first hour of war. Another 325m would have died from radioactive fallout over the following six months. Even if China stayed out of this prospective war, the fallout would kill as many as 300m of its citizens.

;

;“I thought of the Wannsee conference,” wrote John Rubel, an American defence official present at one nuclear-planning meeting, referring to a gathering of Nazi officials in a suburb of Berlin in January 1942, at which they prepared the systematic extermination of European Jews. “I felt as if I were witnessing a comparable descent into the deep heart of darkness.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In “Nuclear War: a Scenario” Annie Jacobsen, a journalist and the author of several books on military affairs, tells Mr Rubel's story as a preface to her own non-fiction account of a hypothetical North Korean nuclear attack on America and the ensuing spiral which consumes the world. Her book is at once methodical and vivid, technically grounded and at times lurid.

;

;The American satellites which pick up the North Korean launch have sensors “so powerful they can see a single lighted match from 200 miles away”, she writes. Within 15 seconds radars can work out that the missile is headed for America. It will take just over half an hour to arrive. Once the president has been briefed he has six minutes to make a choice.

;

;Ms Jacobsen coolly lays out the speed with which entire countries can be snuffed out. A Russian submarine off America's west coast could launch its full complement of missiles at all 50 states at once in 80 seconds. Even if an American submarine was close behind it could not fire a torpedo in that time, notes one expert. That fact is said to have shocked America's navy chief when it was revealed to him in 1981. Missiles launched from close to the American coastline would take little over seven minutes to hit their target.

;

;“Nuclear War” sits in the long tradition of didactic nuclear dystopia.这一类型在 20 世纪 80 年代蓬勃发展，推出了一系列电影——《后天》、《线索》和《战争游戏》（该片制作于 20 年前，但当时被认为太令人震惊而无法上映），这些电影反映了当代fears that the cold-war arms race was spinning out of control.

;

;The genre receded in the 1990s and 2000s: nuclear weapons were tools of过去。 Yet Russia's invasion of Ukraine has put them squarely back at the forefront of geopolitics and culture. Consider the success of Christopher Nolan's biopic of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the father of the atomic bomb, and the commercial revival of “American Prometheus”, the book on which that film was based.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;There is a cinematic quality to Ms Jacobsen's scenario, too. In her account, the president is rushed onto a helicopter to escape to a mountain hideout. He is harangued by generals to retaliate quickly. “If somebody launches a nuclear weapon against us,” says General John Hyten, a former commander of American nuclear forces, “we launch one back.” William Perry, Bill Clinton's secretary of defence, tells Ms Jacobsen that once an incoming missile is detected “we prepare to launch…We do not wait”. The aim is to “decapitate” North Korea—destroy its leadership and command—before it can fire more missiles.

;

;Ms Jacobsen conveys the reality of nuclear war in sometimes stomach-churning detail. In her imagined scenario a North Korean missile obliterates a nuclear-power station north of Los Angeles, seeding spent fuel into the fallout. Victims of the ;X;-ray flash are left “a shredded horror of bloody tendons and exposed bone”. Another bomb destroys Washington, ;DC;. Firestorms bring winds of 660 degrees Celsius; people are baked alive in the bowels of the Capitol and White House. In documenting the minutiae of the apocalypse, the writing is redolent of “Hiroshima”, a seminal article by John Hersey published in the ;New Yorker ;in 1946.

;

;The story is about not just nuclear use, but nuclear war. Ms Jacobsen's narrative is built on an elaborate sequence of tragic misunderstandings. American missiles bound for North Korea must overfly Russia by dint of geography. American leaders cannot get Russia's president on the phone. Russia's sub-par early-warning satellites, which have indeed been known to confuse clouds for plumes, mistakenly see hundreds of missiles incoming. The Kremlin attacks America. America responds. There are 100 “aimpoints”—jargon for targets—in the greater Moscow area alone.

;

;It is possible to quibble with details in Ms Jacobsen's设想。 It is hard to see why North Korea would risk a suicidal bolt from the blue. America might have a “launch on warning” policy, but as Dick Cheney, a former defence secretary and vice-president, has observed, “realistically, most presidents wouldn't do it”. And would Russian leaders truly end the world based on data from faulty sensors?

;

;What is not in dispute, however, and what has receded from public understanding over the last 30 years, is the world-changing impact of nuclear weapons. The vast injection of soot into the atmosphere would result in a 70% reduction in the sun's rays for a decade. Rainfall would decline by 50%. “After 10,000 years of planting and harvesting,” writes Ms Jacobsen, “humans return to a hunter-gatherer state”.

;

;And yet humans continue to deploy, maintain and build nuclear weapons. In “Countdown” Sarah Scoles, a science journalist, profiles the people who work in America's vast complex of nuclear laboratories, including Los Alamos in New Mexico (where Oppenheimer oversaw the invention and construction of the first nuclear bomb), the nearby Sandia labs, and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. The most compelling parts of her book are those in which she explores how these scientists, like Oppenheimer, reconcile their work with their principles.

;

;Some are gung-ho about the importance of nuclear deterrence, brandishing charts which show how deaths from major wars plummeted after the invention of the bomb. Others are equivocal, expressing opposition to nuclear weapons while insisting that someone has to ensure that the ones which exist remain safe and reliable. Still others seem deeply conflicted, preferring to emphasise the civilian applications of their research. “I wonder if the activists on the outside understand that there are those of us on the inside that share many of their goals,” says one scientist at Los Alamos, professing support for (eventual) disarmament. “That's not an extreme position here at all.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;A generational divide also shines through “Countdown”. Before 1992 America kept its nuclear weapons in good order by explosive testing. “People would just get on the airplane in the morning, go down [to Nevada] and blow shit up in the desert,” says Rob Neely, head of simulations and computing at Livermore, with a hint of contempt. “It wasn't until they shook the Earth that they really felt confident.” As America designs a new warhead, the ;W;93, for the first time in decades, some scientists of that era are sceptical that it can be done without testing. Mr Neely's generation relies on computer modelling, aided by the world's largest supercomputers and other technical wizardry. “We've got a new generation of designers coming up,” says Mr Neely. In a digital world, “the codes are their test site.”

;

;Ms Scoles has written a balanced and readable book, one which conveys the attitudes of nuclear disarmers and deterrence advocates alike. What is striking is that even among those who believe that nuclear modernisation is essential in a world where China's arsenal is growing and Russia's becoming more diverse, there is profound ambivalence about the consequences of this and the precariousness of deterrence. Nuclear weapons “will either have a pacifying effect or a catastrophic effect”, acknowledges Brad Roberts, the author of “The Case for ;US; Nuclear Weapons in the 21st Century” and once the Pentagon's top nuclear official. “Monday, Wednesday, Friday, I feel one way. Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday, another,” he tells Ms Scoles. “Then Sunday I drink.” ;■;

; ;N;;arendra Modi;, ;India's prime minister;, is often lumped together with right-wing populists such as Donald Trump or Viktor Orban. On the surface, the comparison is plausible. In 2019 Mr Modi told the ;Indian Express;, a newspaper, that his electoral success was not down to “the Khan Market gang or Lutyens Delhi”, monikers for India's old establishment. Rather, Mr Modi said, he pulled himself up through “45 years of toil”. But the prime minister, who is expected to win a third term after India goes to the polls in April, is no ordinary strongman.

;

;In most places support for anti-establishment populists, such as Mr Trump, and policies such as Brexit tends to be inversely correlated with university education.不在印度。称之为莫迪悖论。 It helps explain why he is the most popular leader of any major democracy today.

;

;A study in 2020 by Cristóbal Kaltwasser and Steven van Hauwaert, two political scientists, of Britain, Turkey, eight countries in the European Union and five in Latin America, confirmed the inverse relationship between higher education and support for populist leaders.这并不具有普遍性：例如，雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗得到了巴西一些受过最好教育的人的支持。 But in America the trend is strong. In December 2023 Gallup found that just 26% of respondents with a university education approved of Mr Trump, compared with 50% of those without.

;;
; ;;;;

;Mr Modi bucks this trend altogether (see chart). In 2017 66% of Indians who had no more than a primary-school education told Pew Research that they had a “very favourable” view of Mr Modi. The number rose to 80% among Indians with at least some higher education. After the previous general election, in 2019, Lokniti-;CSDS;, a pollster, found that around 42% of Indians with a degree supported Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (;BJP);, while around 35% of those with only a primary-school education did. Polls conducted after state elections in 2023 confirm the trend. In Karnataka, for example, 45% of university-educated respondents supported the ;BJP;. Just 32% of respondents who went to primary school did.

;;

;A psephological puzzle

;

;Mr Modi's success among the well-educated does not come at the expense of support among other groups. Indeed, like other populist leaders, his biggest inroads have been made among lower-class voters, says Neelanjan Sircar, a political scientist at the Centre for Policy Research, a think-tank in Delhi. In 2020 Sanjay Kumar of the Centre for the Study of Developing Societies found that between 2014 and 2019 support for the ;BJP; increased among rural, lower-caste, young and poor voters.它在占人口近一半的“其他落后阶层”中增长得尤其快。 Among them, the ;BJP;'s support rose from 34% to 44%, compared with an increase of 31% to 37.5% among all voters.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This pattern of support for the ;BJP; is comparable to other countries in which less-educated or rural people have shifted right. But unlike many of his counterparts abroad, Mr Modi has also been able to increase his support among the educated. Three factors—class politics, economics, and elite admiration for strongman rule—help explain why.

;

;Start with class. In India this is heavily intertwined with the caste system. The ;BJP;, like many conservative parties, is known to be business-friendly. A core constituency includes much of the “Bania” trader community, a traditionally business-oriented group concentrated in north-western states such as Gujarat and Rajasthan.印度首富穆克什·安巴尼（Mukesh Ambani）和高塔姆·阿达尼（Gautam Adani）等大亨就属于这一类。 Upper-caste Hindus, including Kshatriyas and Brahmins, are also part of the core support base. Some regional parties, such as the ;DMK; in Tamil Nadu, have positioned themselves against such upper-caste groups. Congress, the main national opposition party, has championed preferential access to education and government jobs for lower castes.

;

;Mr Modi, himself from a relatively low caste, has marketed the ;BJP; as a caste-agnostic “pan-Hindu” party, allowing him to retain support from high-caste groups while extending the party's reach to others. Mr Sircar notes that the well-educated professional class across India broadly does not identify with the bureaucrats, researchers and media types in Delhi. So Mr Modi's antipathy to the capital's elite has not cost him support among others elsewhere.

;

;The second factor is economic. Annual ;GDP; growth was 8.4% in the last quarter of 2023 (though because of quirks in how India measures its ;GDP;, the underlying figure is closer to 6.5%). That growth, albeit unequally distributed, is driving a rapid increase in the size and wealth of the Indian upper-middle class. Goldman Sachs has called this phenomenon the rise of “affluent India”. It calculates that the number of Indians with an annual income of $10,000 or more grew from 20m in 2011 to 60m in 2023, and will hit 100m by 2027. One rough indicator of this is sales of vehicles.自疫情爆发前以来，汽车销量（通常由较富裕的印度人购买）增长了约 15%。 Sales of two-wheelers, which poorer folk buy, have fallen by just as much.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It is not surprising that Mr Modi has retained the support of those who have become richer.在2000年代末快速发展的时期，国大党在中上层阶级中得到了强有力的支持。 It took a slowdown and a series of corruption scandals in the 2010s to change things.

;

;But Mr Modi's tenure has increased India's economic and geopolitical standing in the world, too.孟买的一位基金经理表示，她的朋友们担心莫迪当选总理后人们对印度的看法。 2002 年，他在古吉拉特邦针对穆斯林的血腥骚乱期间担任首席部长，这次事件导致他的美国签证被拒长达九年。她认为莫迪先生可能会成为全球的贱民。事实上，情况恰恰相反。 Partly because of India's economic heft, and its importance as a counterweight to China, Mr Modi has been welcomed with open arms by leaders worldwide.

;

;Bigger, better...strongman ?

;

;Many university-educated Indians say they dislike Mr Modi's weaponisation of law enforcement against opposition parties and his government's treatment of Muslims as second-class公民。 The arrest on March 21st of ;Arvind Kejriwal;, the chief minister of Delhi, amplified these concerns.尽管如此，正如孟买的一位银行家指出的那样，人们普遍认为莫迪的优点多于缺点。 Indeed, some think a dose of strongman rule is exactly what India needs.

;

;This is the third reason for the prime minister's popularity among elites.他们以中国和东亚四小龙为例，认为这些国家的经验表明强有力的治理可以消除经济增长的障碍。印度南部的一位实业家表示，考虑到该国的收入水平，该国“可能过于民主”。 Mr Modi, he adds, can “get shit done”.

;

;India's elites see Mr Modi's foreign policy as nationalist yet pragmatic.他们喜欢他以与其他反全球化强人类似的方式对西方自由机构和媒体嗤之以鼻，同时促进印度的利益。 Mr Modi has negotiated four new trade deals since 2021, most recently with a grouping of four non-;EU; European countries on March 10th. In February, at the Raisina Dialogue in Delhi—India's version of the Munich Security Conference—his ministers lamented the ;UN;'s antiquated structure, while also positioning India as the leader of the global south.

;

;Admiration for leaders perceived as decisive is not new among India's elite. 20世纪70年代，印度最著名的实业家之一JRD塔塔据说对英迪拉·甘地实施“紧急状态”表示赞赏，即暂停正常的民主进程两年，以应对她的权力受到的威胁。皮尤研究中心 2 月份发布的一项调查发现，67% 的印度人认为“一个强有力的领导人可以在不受议会或法院干预的情况下做出决定的制度将是治理国家的好方法”。这一数字高于 2017 年的 55%，是接受调查的 24 个国家中最高的。 Many internationally minded Indians say Mr Trump is too autocratic for America but that Mr Modi is the right man for their country.

;

;So what could shake Mr Modi's elite fan base?国家持续武器化，就像凯杰里瓦尔先生的例子一样，可能会反过来咬他一口。大多数精英仍然表示他们相信民主。许多自称喜欢首相的人也害怕他，包括那些知道自己的生存取决于保持他的好感的商界人士。这存在风险：根据咨询公司 Henley and Partners 的数据，2022 年和 2023 年印度百万富翁净流出量为 14,000 人，超过除中国以外的任何国家，包括俄罗斯。 By contrast Australia, Singapore and the ;UAE;, and five other countries, attracted over 1,000 millionaires in net inflows—reflecting, perhaps, their more predictable rule of law.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;But for those who stay, even intensified autocracy may not be enough to weaken Mr Modi's appeal. In 2019 India's economy, reeling from a mini-financial crisis, slowed to a growth rate of 4%.尽管这种弱点并不完全是莫迪先生的错，但他在 2016 年迅速废除大额纸币的冲动决定并没有起到任何作用。 Elites complained, but apparently felt that Mr Modi was better for their wallets than the opposition, and voted for him.

;

;This is why many say that support for Mr Modi will continue until a credible alternative appears.大多数精英已经对国会及其领导人拉胡尔·甘地失去了信心，因为他被视为王朝式的、脱离现实的人。一位国会高级官员甚至承认，莫迪先生“采纳了我们最好的想法”，例如以数字方式分配福利金，并且比他的政党“更好地执行了这些想法”。更强大的反对派可能是导致印度精英抛弃莫迪的唯一因素。但就目前而言，还看不到这一点。 ;■;

;;A ;;merica's 45th; president has excellent taste in ;Bible translations;.在决定今年复活节支持哪一部作品时，唐纳德·特朗普选择了詹姆斯国王的版本，该版本被广泛认为是 17 世纪最伟大的英国文学作品之一。 Or rather, he chose a modern repackaging of it dubbed the “God Bless the ;USA; Bible”. This includes in one volume the American constitution, the lyrics of a country song called “God Bless the ;USA;” and the scriptures.

;

;“All Americans need the Bible in their home, and I have many.这是我最喜欢的书，”特朗普在宣传视频中说道。 “宗教非常重要，”他补充道。 “We must make America pray again.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And, tacitly, pay again: the new book costs $59.99 (plus postage). Mr Trump is not selling it directly, but receives royalties with each purchase, according to the ;New York Times;. Thus, he has entered the highly competitive business of trying to make a buck from the holy book.

;

;This is a new kind of venture for Mr Trump, whose previous offerings have tended to be flashier: gold-finished Trump sneakers for $399, an enticing Trump cologne for $99.圣经绝不是奢侈品，而是对财富的猛烈攻击。它讲述了一个男人的生活，他说过“穷人有福了”和“爱你的敌人”。 Such sentiments are not easily mistaken for those of Mr Trump, which include “Part of the beauty of me is that I am very rich” and “The worst thing a man can do is go bald.”

;

;The market in religious publishing is thriving in America: the recent StatShot Annual Report from the Association of American Publishers found that revenues of religious presses had risen 7% in the first ten months of 2023, to $674m. A slice of that might defray at least some of Mr Trump's legal expenses, but this is a very unusual market, with obstacles for new entrants.

;

;The biggest is that many suppliers insist on giving its most popular product away for free.成立于 1899 年的基督教慈善机构吉迪恩斯 (The Gideons) 已将 25 亿本《圣经》和《新约》放置在世界各地的酒店、医院、监狱和家庭暴力庇护所中，大约相当于每个基督徒男人、女人和儿童一本。渴望真理的疲惫旅行者只需伸手到床头柜抽屉里就能找到一些。其他团体已将整本圣经发布到网上，以便信徒可以搜索他们最喜欢的经文。 Against such unfair, cut-price competition, can Mr Trump compete?

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Probably, for several reasons.首先，他所宣扬的受人尊敬的文本不受版权保护——这个概念在 1611 年《英皇钦定版圣经》首次出版时还不存在。因此，他对一本早已去世的作者不需要支付费用的文本要价很高。 。别介意在小先知书的页边空白处做笔记；这本书每本的利润率应该很大。

;

;None of that will matter if no one buys the God Bless the ;USA; Bible. But it has two celebrity endorsements: Lee Greenwood, the country star who sings “God Bless the ;USA;”, is involved, too. And Mr Trump is pushing the tome during a bitter election campaign, to a vast number of followers, many of whom are passionate both about scripture and about supporting the former president against his fiendish enemies.

;

;Others in the devotional publishing industry have faced the same challenge as Mr Trump—how to refresh a blockbuster written thousands of years ago—and come up with even more creative solutions.他们无法像阿加莎·克里斯蒂和伊恩·弗莱明的文学庄园那样委托在世作家创作续集来创作新的赫尔克里·波洛和詹姆斯·邦德故事。 But they can commission new translations (a huge task) or tailor versions for specific audiences.

;

;Thus, from Zondervan, the Christian arm of HarperCollins, you can buy the “Boys Bible” (“Gross and gory stuff you never knew was in the Bible”).德国一家规模较小的机构出版了《骑车人圣经》（“整本新约圣经和骑车人的生活故事”）。 《圣经》篇幅长且令人困惑：许多现代读者渴望找到可能特别相关的段落的捷径，以及有助于理解的注释。其他人则寻求奇思妙想：您可以购买“母亲的圣经”（粉红色）或地方方言的圣经（格拉斯哥语的圣经以“开始”开头）。 There are even scriptures in fictitious tongues such as Klingon, from “Star Trek”, or Quenya, invented by JRR Tolkien.

;

;Such experimentation is much easier with the Bible than it is with the Koran, and much easier today than in previous centuries. 16世纪，学者威廉·廷代尔（William Tyndale）将《圣经》从希伯来语和希腊语翻译成英语，其方式引起了教会的不满。后来他因异端邪说被烧死在火刑柱上。 The church was less tolerant of novelty in those days, and created literal ghostwriters.

;

;Since many people take the Bible literally, careful proofreading is essential 。 1631 年，伦敦的印刷商无意中将第七条诫命中的“不”一词漏掉，从而将其翻译为“不可通奸”。这让许多读者感到高兴，但当局却不高兴。印刷商被处以巨额罚款并被吊销执照。 《邪恶圣经》随后成为收藏品；幸存的副本现在价值数万美元。子孙后代是否会如此珍视特朗普的《圣经》还有待观察。 ■

;;T;;HE IDEA; of machines outsmarting humans has long been the subject of science fiction. Rapid improvements in artificial-intelligence (;AI;) programs over the past decade have led some experts to conclude that science fiction could soon become fact. On March 19th ;Jensen Huang;, the chief executive of Nvidia, the world's biggest manufacturer of computer chips and its third most valuable publicly traded company, said he believed today's models could advance to the point of so-called artificial general intelligence (;AGI;) within five years. What exactly is ;AGI;—and how can we judge when it has arrived?

;

;Mr Huang's words should be taken with a pinch of salt: Nvidia's profits have soared because of the ;growing demand for its high-tech chips;, which are used to train ;AI; models. Promoting ;AI; is thus good for business. But Mr Huang did set out a clear definition of what he believes would constitute ;AGI;: a program that can do 8% better than most people at certain tests, such as bar exams for lawyers or logic quizzes.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;This proposal is the latest in a long line of definitions. In the 1950s Alan Turing, a British mathematician, said that talking to a model that had achieved ;AGI; would be indistinguishable from talking to a human. Arguably the most advanced ;large language models; already pass the Turing test.但近年来，科技领导者提出了一系列新的定义，从而改变了目标。 ;Mustafa Suleyman;, co-founder of DeepMind, an ;AI;-research firm, and chief executive of a newly established AI division within Microsoft, believes that what he calls “artificial capable intelligence”—a “modern Turing test”—will have been reached when a model is given $100,000 and turns it into $1m without instruction. (Mr Suleyman is a board member of ;The Economist;'s parent company.) Steve Wozniak, a co-founder of Apple, has a more prosaic vision of ;AGI;: a machine that can enter an average home and make a cup of coffee.

;

;Some researchers reject the concept of ;AGI; altogether 。伦敦国王学院的迈克·库克表示，这个词没有科学依据，而且对不同的人有不同的含义。 Few definitions of ;AGI; attract consensus, admits Harry Law, of the University of Cambridge, but most are based on the idea of a model that can outperform humans at most tasks—whether making coffee or making millions. In January researchers at DeepMind proposed six levels of ;AGI;, ranked by the proportion of skilled adults that a model can outperform: they say the technology has reached only the lowest level, with ;AI; tools equal to or slightly better than an ;unskilled human;.

;

;The question of what happens when we reach ;AGI; obsesses some研究人员。 Eliezer Yudkowsky, a computer scientist who has been fretting about AI for 20 years, worries that by the time people recognise that models have ;become sentient;, it will be too late to stop them and humans will become enslaved.但很少有研究人员同意他的观点。 Most believe that ;AI; is simply following human inputs, often poorly.

;There may be no consensus about what constitutes ;AGI; among academics or businessmen—but a definition could soon be agreed on in court. As part of a ;lawsuit; lodged in February against OpenAI, a company he co-founded, Elon Musk is asking a court in California to decide whether the firm's ;GPT-4; model shows signs of ;AGI;. If it does, Mr Musk claims, OpenAI has gone against its founding principle that it will license only pre-;AGI; technology.该公司否认曾这样做。马斯克正在通过他的律师寻求陪审团审判。 Should his wish be granted, a handful of non-experts could decide a question that has vexed ;AI; experts for decades. ;■;
